Sales forecast with an ARIMA model

I'm trying to understand if an ARIMA model could be improved. This is my dataset ( sales ): 28.35, 51.89, 37.26, 48.22, 30.93, 43.54, 35.3, 59.45, 49.41, 65.61, 36.59, 51.25, 31.42, 53.16, 39.41, 64.45, 43.94, 79.36, 52.93, 74.99, 55.03, 86.93, 41.69, 62.77, 227.47, 329.25, 238.65, 363.8, 280.39, 453.38, 363.84, 486.65, 647.67, 534.41, 219.69, 292.16, 209.73, 336.33, 226.43, 336.23, 249.48, 359.84, 188.05, 307.73, 231.67, 330.43, 252.22, 379.3, 293.54, 413.67, 384.64, 515.86, 482.36, 438.12 sales = as.ts(sales, frequency=2) Two data each week. In this time series I see seasonality and trend. Correct me if I'm wrong. After a log transformation to stabilize variance: sales.transformed The model given by auto.arima is: fit But residuals don't behave like white noise: res Then I tried a seasonal ARIMA model. fit Things are getting better: Series: sales.transformed ARIMA(3,1,1)(2,0,1)[2] Coefficients: ar1 ar2 ar3 ma1 sar1 sar2 sma1 -1.3075 0.2398 0.5474 0.9721 0.0648 -0.0803 -0.7839 s.e. 0.0630 0.1221 0.1010 0.0401 0.0848 0.0657 0.0606 sigma^2 estimated as 0.02667: log likelihood=131.05 AIC=-246.09 AICc=-245.65 BIC=-215.48 Now things are even better. ARIMA(5,1,0) with drift Box Cox transformation: lambda= 0 Coefficients: ar1 ar2 ar3 ar4 ar5 drift -0.4224 0.0143 -0.2956 -0.0849 -0.3238 0.0015 s.e. 0.0516 0.0563 0.0541 0.0564 0.0516 0.0009 sigma^2 estimated as 0.001257: log likelihood=649.72 AIC=-1285.44 AICc=-1285.1 BIC=-1258.65 I don't know if the model can be improved or if this is the best an ARIMA can do, given my time series. I should probably try with autoregressive mixed models and add new predictors... Any advice would be really appreciated.
